issue.title: Upgrade reqwest to build on openssl 1.1.1

repository.name: maturin
repository.description: Build and publish crates with pyo3, cffi and uniffi bindings as well as rust binaries as python packages

body: Weird! Would it be possible to add something like [pretty_env_logger](https://crates.io/crates/pretty_env_logger) (or your preferred logger) with logs like `RUST_LOG=hyper,reqwest`, and include them? (Of course, if the request or response would contain sensitive info, be sure to remove it from the logs before pasting.)

Sure. Minimal example:

```
RUST_LOG=hyper cargo run
   Compiling sslbug v0.1.0 (/home/konsti/sslbug)                                                                                                                             
    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 12.60s                                                                                                               
     Running `target/debug/sslbug`
thread 'main' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: Error { kind: Io(Custom { kind: WouldBlock, error: StringError("timed out") }), url: None }', libcore/result.rs:1009:5
note: Run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` for a backtrace.
 TRACE hyper::client::pool > checkout waiting for idle connection: ("https://test.pypi.org", Http1)
 TRACE hyper::client::connect::http > Http::connect; scheme=https, host=test.pypi.org, port=None
 DEBUG hyper::client::dns           > resolving host="test.pypi.org", port=443
 DEBUG hyper::client::connect::http > connecting to [2a04:4e42:1b::319]:443
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > read_keep_alive; is_mid_message=false
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > flushed({role=client}): State { reading: Init, writing: Init, keep_alive: Busy, error: None }
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > read_keep_alive; is_mid_message=false
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::role       > Client::encode method=POST, body=Some(Unknown)
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::encode     > sized write, len = 8192
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::io         > detected no usage of vectored write, flattening
 DEBUG hyper::proto::h1::io         > flushed 214 bytes
 DEBUG hyper::proto::h1::io         > flushed 8192 bytes
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > flushed({role=client}): State { reading: Init, writing: Closed, keep_alive: Busy, error: None }
```

pyo3-pack:

```
RUST_LOG=hyper,reqwest cargo run -- publish -u konstin -b bin -r https://test.pypi.org/legacy/ -m hello-world/Cargo.toml -p notmypassword
   Compiling pyo3-pack v0.3.4 (/home/konsti/pyo3-pack)                                                                                                                       
    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 17.61s                                                                                                               
     Running `target/debug/pyo3-pack publish -u konstin -b bin -r 'https://test.pypi.org/legacy/' -m hello-world/Cargo.toml -p notmypassword`
Warning: You're publishing debug wheels
Built wheel to /home/konsti/pyo3-pack/target/wheels/hello_world-0.1.0-py2.py3-none-manylinux1_x86_64.whl
Uploading 1 packages
 TRACE hyper::client::pool > checkout waiting for idle connection: ("https://test.pypi.org", Http1)
 TRACE hyper::client::connect::http > Http::connect; scheme=https, host=test.pypi.org, port=None
 DEBUG hyper::client::dns           > resolving host="test.pypi.org", port=443
 DEBUG hyper::client::connect::http > connecting to [2a04:4e42:1b::319]:443
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > read_keep_alive; is_mid_message=false
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > flushed({role=client}): State { reading: Init, writing: Init, keep_alive: Busy, error: None }
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > read_keep_alive; is_mid_message=false
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::role       > Client::encode method=POST, body=Some(Unknown)
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::encode     > sized write, len = 8192
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::io         > detected no usage of vectored write, flattening
 DEBUG hyper::proto::h1::io         > flushed 264 bytes
 DEBUG hyper::proto::h1::io         > flushed 8192 bytes
 TRACE hyper::proto::h1::conn       > flushed({role=client}): State { reading: Init, writing: Closed, keep_alive: Busy, error: None }
```
Ok, I've discovered the error, it's around improperly handling back pressure on sending request bodies. It only happens when the body is bigger than 8192 bytes. Fix coming in a few minutes.

Thanks for tackling so fast, but I fear this isn't fully resolved yet. When I now run

```
RUST_LOG=hyper,reqwest cargo run -- publish -u konstin -b bin -r https://test.pypi.org/legacy/ -m hello-world/Cargo.toml -p notmypassword
```

it works as expected, but I run this without the `RUST_LOG` part, i.e. just

```
cargo run -- publish -u konstin -b bin -r https://test.pypi.org/legacy/ -m hello-world/Cargo.toml -p notmypassword
```

I get:

```
https://test.pypi.org/legacy/: connection closed
https://test.pypi.org/legacy/: connection closed
```

For the minimized example, I have the panic in the log again both when running with `RUST_LOG=hyper cargo run` and with `cargo run`.
Sorry, what's the difference between runs?
Sorry, I failed at copy and pasting. Edited.
So that I understand, you're saying it works correctly with `RUST_LOG` set, but with it disabled, it fails? About how big is the file being sent?
The test suite shows the same behavior. `RUST_BACKTRACE=full cargo test --test multipart` fails while `RUST_LOG=hyper,reqwest RUST_BACKTRACE=full cargo test --test multipart` passes.

I made I repo with minimal reproduction: https://github.com/konstin/reqwest_348. Just `cargo run` causes the panic for me. The repo uses a 4MB file. Using a 47MB file also works, it just runs longer till failure.

I had some difficulty reproducing in the test suite locally since the socket buffers never fill, but found a way to trigger what was happening. Latest master should have a new fix for it spuriously thinking the connection is closed.
